contents.context:
South Korean President Moon Jae-in could increase the country's "constructive contribution" to building global peace and cooperation.
That's according to experts speaking to Arirang News.
Since 2017, Moon has focused on building peace across the border with North Korea, and bringing the denuclearization agenda back to the dialogue table.

"It's been of course President Moon's ability to persuade Donald Trump to commit political capital and time into developing his own N. Korea policy, which of course has paid off with three critical summits. The president therefore was a uniquely important catalyst in getting the Americans and the North Koreans together. I think he's shown not only political courage but a shrewd degree of political psychology"

Recently Moon has extended his initiative for peace and cooperation amid the COVID-19 crisis.

"We've seen also of course some high profile cases of foreign leaders explicitly trying to learn the lessons from the S. Korean experience or in some cases the Irish taoisaech has sought and received technical assistance from S. Korea, countries around the world or state governments, the governor of Maryland and the U.S. strikingly receiving PPE, important equipment from S. Korea.."

This has boosted the South Korean leader's status, giving him room to further extend Korea's positive contribution to the world.

"It's really riding the wave with BTS, with Hallyu, with director Bong Jun-ho and Parasite. There's a lot of goodwill towards S. Korea. So it does have this opportunity to be a beacon in NE Asia of democracy, positive responses to global pandemics, to diplomacy, to goodwill among nations and towards its own citizens."

Moon Jae-in on Sunday vowed to turn the COVID-19 crisis into an opportunity so that South Korea can take a leading role in the world.
Oh Soo-young, Arirang News.
Reporter : osy@arirang.com
contents.headline:
Amid world leadership vacuum, S. Korea could play positive role in promoting democracy, fast COVID-19 response: experts
Updated: 2020-05-11 17:12:51 KST

contents.context:
The director-general of the Korea Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, Jung Eun-kyeong, has been gaining worldwide recognition for her role in containing the outbreak.
The latest to laud her leadership is Japan's Yomiuri Shimbun.
The Japanese daily details how Jung is hailed in Korea as a "true hero" and that a growing number of Koreans has urged the government to nominate her as the next Director-General of the World Health Organization.
The paper notes her calm voice during daily press briefings as a strength that's helped the government gain the public's trust adding she's the first woman to lead the KCDC.
Reporter : jiyeonkim@arirang.co.kr
contents.headline:
KCDC chief Jung Eun-kyeong recognized in overseas media
Updated: 2020-05-11 17:07:11 KST

contents.context:
Fresh COVID-19 outbreaks in countries considered to have made strides in flattening the curve have highlighted the risk of easing up on social distancing measures.
The Associated Press cited a surge in new cases over the weekend at slaughterhouses in Germany as well as at multiple nightclubs in South Korea.
It stated both countries have conducted massive contact tracing and testing and have been praised for their relatively low number of COVID-19 deaths.
The report said people are more likely to stop following guidelines once measures are relaxed while the risk of a resurgence linger.
Reporter : jiyeonkim@arirang.co.kr
contents.headline:
New COVID-19 outbreaks in Germany, S. Korea highlight risks of easing social distancing: AP
Updated: 2020-05-11 10:10:20 KST

contents.context:
The U.S. unemployment rate reached 14.seven percent in April, a rate last seen during the Great Depression.
That's not to say it has reached the peak either.
U.S. Treasury Secretary Steve Mnuchin is warning the rate could hit 25 percent.
He says that, while the Great Depression was an economic crisis, the American economy was forced to almost completely shut down in 2020 because of COVID-19, which is why it's more damaging than the Depression.
To make matters worse, some experts say the jobless numbers aren't as cut and dry as they appear.

"Some experts believe that that's actually 5 percentage points less than what the real unemployment rate is, because many people are around part time work at this point and many people have not even been able to file claims because so many people are trying to file unemployment claims, they simply cannot get through to make the filing."

While experts mostly agree that the worst is yet to come, the Trump administration says it's all hands to the pump to reopen the economy.
Mnuchin told Fox News that more economic plans are on the way to the public.
The White House also assured the American public that there would be a brighter future ahead.

"I can tell you this, the President that got us to the hottest economy in modern history, he's done it once and he can do it again."

President Trump is pushing relentlessly to reopen the economy.
For example, President Trump congratulated Ultimate Fighting Championship and its owner, Dana White, prior to the no-spectator UFC 249 event that happened on Saturday night, local time, in Jacksonville, Florida.
On the other hand, the situation within the administration suggests the virus is still a danger.
A couple employees in the White House have tested positive for COVID-19, including President Trump's valet and Vice President Mike Pence's press secretary.
Kim Do-yeon, Arirang News.
Reporter : tkim@arirang.com
contents.headline:
U.S. unemployment rate still rising as Trump pushes to reopen economy
Updated: 2020-05-11 10:08:53 KST

contents.context:
In January, COVID-19 sprouted up in the Chinese city of Wuhan, quickly spreading to neighboring countries, such as Hong Kong and Singapore.
Around that time, the World Health Organization held a two-day emergency meeting.
However, the outbreak was not declared a pandemic.

"This is, though, an emergency in China. But it has not yet become a global health emergency. It may yet become one.

Citing BND, Germany's federal intelligence service, German media reports that there are suspicions the WHO's decision to delay the pandemic declaration was caused by pressure from Chinese President Xi Jinping.
The report says Xi called for a meeting with the WHO chief on January 21st, and asked for the pandemic warning to be delayed.
Even when South Korea saw its first infection on January 20th, followed by the U.S.'s first infection the following day, the WHO did not declare a global pandemic, a decision the BND estimates resulted in the loss of four to six weeks in the fight against COVID-19.
The WHO released a statement, calling the allegations "unfounded and untrue", adding the WHO chief and President Xi did not speak on January 21st, nor have they ever spoken by phone.
The WHO continued to say China confirmed human-to-human transmission to the UN health agency on January 20th, and that the agency "publicly declared" two days later that such transmission was taking place in Wuhan.
The statements also come as President Trump has blasted China for holding back critical information about the virus, including its failure to accurately report on the number of cases.
Lee Seung-jae, Arirang News.
Reporter : seungjae86@gmail.com
contents.headline:
China pressured WHO to delay global COVID-19 warning: report
Updated: 2020-05-11 10:08:53 KST

contents.context:
The U.S. Food and Drug Administration has approved the first antigen test that can quickly detect whether a person has COVID-19.
The test kit which was created by Quidel Corporation, was given emergency use authorization late Friday by the FDA.
Unlike other COVID-19 tests which use PCR, this test uses antigen diagnostics, and detects fragments of the virus in a sample.
The test will rely on specimens collected from nasal swabs, and can provide results in 15 minutes.
However, experts say while antigen tests are extremely accurate in detecting positive infections, they cannot detect all active infections and have a higher chance of false negatives than PCR tests.
Reporter : seungjae86@gmail.com
contents.headline:
U.S. FDA approves first antigen test kit for COVID-19
Updated: 2020-05-11 10:00:17 KST

contents.context:
Over in the U.S.
Vice President Mike Pence's press secretary tested positive for the coronavirus.
Katie Miller's Covid-19 contraction again brought the danger of the virus to the White House inner circle.
One of President Donald Trump's personal valets tested positive as well.
Robert Redfield, director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention "had a low-risk exposure" to "a person at the White House who has COVID-19."
Dr. Anthony Fauci, the director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases and member of the White House's coronavirus task force, told CNN he will begin a "modified quarantine" after making a "low risk" contact with the oval office staffer who tested positive for the virus.
FDA commissioner Stephen Hahn, began self-quarantining after being exposed to an individual who tested positive for the coronavirus.
Reporter : danc@arirang.co.kr
contents.headline:
White House, CDC, FDA personnel quarantined
Updated: 2020-05-10 12:13:08 KST

contents.context:
The IMF signalled a possible downward revision of global economic forecasts.
It's managing director said, recent economic data for many countries is pointing below the organization's already pessimistic forecast for a 3 percent contraction this year.
Kristalina Georgieva warned that economic outcomes could be far worse, depending on the course of the pandemic.
The IMF's April projection for a 3 percent contraction would mark the worst downturn since the Great Depression of the 1930s.
Reporter : damikim@arirang.com
contents.headline:
IMF's Georgieva downbeat on global economic forecast due to COVID-19 crisis
Updated: 2020-05-10 08:53:48 KST

contents.context:
The COVID-19 pandemic has reached the White House with two staff members testing positive for the virus.
Vice President Mike Pence's press secretary, Katie Miller, has been confirmed positive on Friday.
On the same day, CNN reported that Ivanka Trump's personal assistant also tested positive though she has been working remotely for the past two months.
All oval office staff, including President Trump, get tested daily for the virus.
Reporter : tommyjang@arirang.com
contents.headline:
COVID-19 hits White House, infecting 2 staff members
Updated: 2020-05-10 08:53:48 KST

contents.context:
Europe is gradually easing lockdown measures as the spread of COVID-19 across the European Region stabilizes.
Some lockdown measures have been rolled back in countries including Italy, France and Germany and Greece is planning to reopen the country to international tourists as early as July.
Athen's Acropolis and other ancient sites in Greece will reopen May 18.
While Denmark will see shopping malls reopen from Monday and will decide on the first of next month whether or not to release the lockdown of the country.
Finally, Norway is set to resume some classes at school next week starting with middle and high school students.
Reporter : jy_rachel@arirang.com
contents.headline:
Countries in Europe easing COVID-19 restrictions
Updated: 2020-05-09 13:34:15 KST

contents.context:
The U.S. continues to have conversations regarding the defense cost-sharing agreement with South Korea as the alliance remains strong.
According to the assistant secretary of state for political-military affairs on Friday, communication between the two countries has never stopped regarding the Special Measures Agreement on cost-dividing for the U.S. army's presence in South Korea.
He said the lines of communication between the two countries' presidents, top diplomats, and top negotiators remain open and active.
He also said the two parties are looking for amenable space to get close on the cost-deal as neither side wants to see the alliance erode.
Reporter : jy_rachel@arirang.com
contents.headline:
U.S. continuing conversations on defense cost-sharing deal with S. Korea: U.S. official
Updated: 2020-05-09 09:57:13 KST

contents.context:
LG Chem is taking all available measures possible to protect everyone affected by the latest gas leak at its Polymers plant in India by cooperating with Indian authorities and the Korean Embassy in New Delhi.
That's according to South Korea's largest chemical company as it denied media reports that there was a second leak at the plant.
Both Indian authorities and LG Chem confirmed that the latest evacuation was precautionary out of concern that rising temperatures at the plant's gas tank could possibly cause another leak.
At least 11 people have been confirmed dead and hundreds more have been hospitalized after a chemical gas leak at a plant owned by LG Polymers, a subsidiary of the South Korean megacorporation LG in Andhra Pradesh state early Thursday.
Reporter : jychoi@arirang.com
contents.headline:
No additional leak around India LG Chem plant confirmed, wider evacuation was a preventive measur
Updated: 2020-05-08 17:30:06 KST
